head.title: Ten of 22 Umpires May Be Rehired

hedline.hl1: Ten of 22 Umpires May Be Rehired

abstract.p: Ten of 22 major league umpires who lost their jobs last year could get those jobs back, but their future employment depends on two agreements: one between Major League Baseball and umpires' new union on new labor contract and one by ousted union to settle its grievance against baseball (S)

block.p: Ten of the 22 major league umpires who lost their jobs last year could get those jobs back. But their future employment depends on two agreements: one between Major League Baseball and the umpires' new union on a new labor contract and one by the ousted union to settle its grievance against baseball.
If the deals are struck, six umpires would leave with retirement packages and six would receive cash settlement packages.

Ten of the 22 major league umpires who lost their jobs last year could get those jobs back. But their future employment depends on two agreements: one between Major League Baseball and the umpires' new union on a new labor contract and one by the ousted union to settle its grievance against baseball.
If the deals are struck, six umpires would leave with retirement packages and six would receive cash settlement packages.

The 10 who would return are Jim Evans, Bob Davidson, Tom Hallion, Gary Darling, Bill Hohn, Larry Vanover, Bruce Dreckman, Ed Hickox, Sam Holbrook and Paul Nauert. The six, all 55 or older, who would be given retirement packages are Richie Garcia, Frank Pulli, Terry Tata, Larry McCoy, Dale Ford and Ken Kaiser. The remaining six, all under 55, who would receive settlements are Drew Coble, Larry Poncino, Joe West, Greg Kosc, Mark Johnson and Eric Gregg.
